column2: During June the meetings of those who were in the secret were frequent. At length, on the last day of the month, the day on which the Bishops were pronounced not guilty, the decisive step was taken.
column3: During June the meetings of those who were in the secret were frequent. At length, on the last day of the month, the day on which the Bishops were pronounced not guilty, the decisive step was taken.

column2: A formal invitation, transcribed by Sidney but drawn up by some person more skilled than Sidney, in the art of composition, was despatched to the Hague.
column3: A formal invitation, transcribed by Sidney but drawn up by some person more skilled than Sidney, in the art of composition, was despatched to the Hague.

column2: If his Highness would appear in the island at the head of some troops, tens of thousands would hasten to his standard.
column3: If his Highness would appear in the island at the head of some troops, tens of thousands would hasten to his standard.

column2: The officers were discontented; and the common soldiers shared that aversion to Popery which was general in the class from which they were taken.
column3: The officers were discontented; and the common soldiers shared that aversion to Popery which was general in the class from which they were taken.

column2: In the navy Protestant feeling was still stronger.
column3: In the navy Protestant feeling was still stronger.

column2: It was important to take some decisive step while things were in this state.
column3: It was important to take some decisive step while things were in this state.

column2: The enterprise would be far more arduous if it were deferred till the King, by remodelling boroughs and regiments, had procured a Parliament and an army on which he could rely.
column3: The enterprise would be far more arduous if it were deferred till the King, by remodelling boroughs and regiments, had procured a Parliament and an army on which he could rely.

column2: The conspirators, therefore, implored the Prince to come among them with as little delay as possible.
column3: The conspirators, therefore, implored the Prince to come among them with as little delay as possible.

column2: On one point they thought it their duty to remonstrate with his Highness.
column3: On one point they thought it their duty to remonstrate with his Highness.

column2: He had not taken advantage of the opinion which the great body of the English people had formed respecting the late birth.
column3: He had not taken advantage of the opinion which the great body of the English people had formed respecting the late birth.

column2: He had, on the contrary, sent congratulations to Whitehall, and had thus seemed to acknowledge that the child who was called Prince of Wales was rightful heir of the throne.
column3: He had, on the contrary, sent congratulations to Whitehall, and had thus seemed to acknowledge that the child who was called Prince of Wales was rightful heir of the throne.

column2: This was a grave error, and had damped the zeal of many.
column3: This was a grave error, and had damped the zeal of many.

column2: Not one person in a thousand doubted that the boy was supposititious; and the Prince would be wanting to his own interests if the suspicious circumstances which had attended the Queen's confinement were not put prominently forward among his reasons for taking arms.
column3: Not one person in a thousand doubted that the boy was supposititious; and the Prince would be wanting to his own interests if the suspicious circumstances which had attended the Queen's confinement were not put prominently forward among his reasons for taking arms.

column2: This paper was signed in cipher by the seven chiefs of the conspiracy, Shrewsbury, Devonshire, Danby, Lumley, Compton, Russell and Sidney. Herbert undertook to be their messenger.
column3: This paper was signed in cipher by the seven chiefs of the conspiracy, Shrewsbury, Devonshire, Danby, Lumley, Compton, Russell and Sidney. Herbert undertook to be their messenger.

column2: His errand was one of no ordinary peril.
column3: His errand was one of no ordinary peril.

column2: He assumed the garb of a common sailor, and in this disguise reached the Dutch coast in safety, on the Friday after the trial of the Bishops.
column3: He assumed the garb of a common sailor, and in this disguise reached the Dutch coast in safety, on the Friday after the trial of the Bishops.

column2: He instantly hastened to the Prince.
column3: He instantly hastened to the Prince.

column2: Bentinck and Dykvelt were summoned, and several days were passed in deliberation.
column3: Bentinck and Dykvelt were summoned, and several days were passed in deliberation.

column2: The first result of this deliberation was that the prayer for the Prince of Wales ceased to be read in the Princess's chapel.
column3: The first result of this deliberation was that the prayer for the Prince of Wales ceased to be read in the Princess's chapel.

column2: From his wife William had no opposition to apprehend.
column3: From his wife William had no opposition to apprehend.

column2: Her understanding had been completely subjugated by his; and, what is more extraordinary, he had won her entire affection.
column3: Her understanding had been completely subjugated by his; and, what is more extraordinary, he had won her entire affection.

column2: He had done all in his power to disturb her domestic happiness, and had established a system of spying, eavesdropping, and talebearing under her roof.
column3: He had done all in his power to disturb her domestic happiness, and had established a system of spying, eavesdropping, and talebearing under her roof.

column2: She had ventured to intercede with him on behalf of her old friend and preceptor Compton, who, for refusing to commit an act of flagitious injustice, had been suspended from his episcopal functions; but she had been ungraciously repulsed.
column3: She had ventured to intercede with him on behalf of her old friend and preceptor Compton, who, for refusing to commit an act of flagitious injustice, had been suspended from his episcopal functions; but she had been ungraciously repulsed.

column2: He had conspired with Tyrconnel and with France against Mary's rights, and had made arrangements for depriving her of one at least of the three crowns to which, at his death, she would have been entitled.
column3: He had conspired with Tyrconnel and with France against Mary's rights, and had made arrangements for depriving her of one at least of the three crowns to which, at his death, she would have been entitled.

column2: That she should love such a father was impossible. Her religious principles, indeed, were so strict that she would probably have tried to perform what she considered as her duty, even to a father whom she did not love.
column3: That she should love such a father was impossible. Her religious principles, indeed, were so strict that she would probably have tried to perform what she considered as her duty, even to a father whom she did not love.

column2: On the present occasion, however, she judged that the claim of James to her obedience ought to yield to a claim more sacred.
column3: On the present occasion, however, she judged that the claim of james to her obedience ought to yield to a claim more sacred.

column2: This is the undoubted rule even when the husband is in the wrong; and to Mary the enterprise which William meditated appeared not only just, but holy.
column3: This is the undoubted rule even when the husband is in the wrong; and to Mary the enterprise which William meditated appeared not only just, but holy.

column2: But, though she carefully abstained from doing or saying anything that could add to his difficulties, those difficulties were serious indeed. They were in truth but imperfectly understood even by some of those who invited him over, and have been but imperfectly described by some of those who have written the history of his expedition.
column3: But, though she carefully abstained from doing or saying anything that could add to his difficulties, those difficulties were serious indeed. They were in truth but imperfectly understood even by some of those who invited him over, and have been but imperfectly described by some of those who have written the history of his expedition.

column2: The obstacles which he might expect to encounter on English ground, though the least formidable of the obstacles which stood in the way of his design, were yet serious.
column3: The obstacles which he might expect to encounter on English ground, though the least formidable of the obstacles which stood in the way of his design, were yet serious.

column2: He felt that it would be madness in him to imitate the example of Monmouth, to cross the sea with a few British adventurers, and to trust to a general rising of the population.
column3: He felt that it would be madness in him to imitate the example of Monmouth, to cross the sea with a few British adventurers, and to trust to a general rising of the population.

column2: It was necessary, and it was pronounced necessary by all those who invited him over, that he should carry an army with him.
column3: It was necessary, and it was pronounced necessary by all those who invited him over, that he should carry an army with him.

column2: Yet who could answer for the effect which the appearance of such an army might produce?
column3: Yet who could answer for the effect which the appearance of such an army might produce?

column2: The government was indeed justly odious.
column3: The government was indeed justly odious.

column2: But would the English people, altogether unaccustomed to the interference of continental powers in English disputes, be inclined to look with favour on a deliverer who was surrounded by foreign soldiers?
column3: But would the English people, altogether unaccustomed to the interference of continental powers in English disputes, be inclined to look with favour on a deliverer who was surrounded by foreign soldiers?

column2: If any part of the royal forces resolutely withstood the invaders, would not that part soon have on its side the patriotic sympathy of millions?
column3: If any part of the royal forces resolutely withstood the invaders, would not that part soon have on its side the patriotic sympathy of millions?

column2: A defeat would be fatal to the whole undertaking.
column3: A defeat would be fatal to the whole undertaking.

column2: These considerations might well have made William uneasy; even if all the military means of the United Provinces had been at his absolute disposal.
column3: These considerations might well have made William uneasy; even if all the military means of the United Provinces had been at his absolute disposal.

column2: The States General could not make war or peace, could not conclude any alliance or levy any tax, without the consent of the States of every province.
column3: The States General could not make war or peace, could not conclude any alliance or levy any tax, without the consent of the States of every province.

column2: The States of a province could not give such consent without the consent of every municipality which had a share in the representation.
column3: The States of a province could not give such consent without the consent of every municipality which had a share in the representation.

column2: Every municipality was, in some sense, a sovereign state, and, as such, claimed the right of communicating directly with foreign ambassadors, and of concerting with them the means of defeating schemes on which other municipalities were intent.
column3: Every municipality was, in some sense, a sovereign state, and, as such, claimed the right of communicating directly with foreign ambassadors, and of concerting with them the means of defeating schemes on which other municipalities were intent.

column2: In some town councils the party which had, during several generations, regarded the influence of the Stadtholders with jealousy had great power.
column3: In some town councils the party which had, during several generations, regarded the influence of the Stadtholders with jealousy had great power.

column2: Propositions brought forward by the Stadtholder as indispensable to the security of the commonwealth, sanctioned by all the provinces except Holland, and sanctioned by seventeen of the eighteen town councils of Holland, had repeatedly been negatived by the single voice of Amsterdam.
column3: Propositions brought forward by the Stadtholder as indispensable to the security of the commonwealth, sanctioned by all the provinces except Holland, and sanctioned by seventeen of the eighteen town councils of Holland, had repeatedly been negatived by the single voice of Amsterdam.

column2: The only constitutional remedy in such cases was that deputies from the cities which were agreed should pay a visit to the city which dissented, for the purpose of expostulation.
column3: The only constitutional remedy in such cases was that deputies from the cities which were agreed should pay a visit to the city which dissented, for the purpose of expostulation.

column2: The number of deputies was unlimited: they might continue to expostulate as long as they thought fit; and meanwhile all their expenses were defrayed by the obstinate community which refused to yield to their arguments.
column3: The number of deputies was unlimited: they might continue to expostulate as long as they thought fit; and meanwhile all their expenses were defrayed by the obstinate community which refused to yield to their arguments.
